#18 Paul -- critical differences between a nor'easter and a hurricane:

Snow may drift, but it doesn't flow, doesn't cause flash flooding, doesn't penetrate your home in the way that rain driven by 40-80 mph wind does. The rain in wind has much more weight than snow and carries much more force against objects. (By the way, tropical weather rain drops are actually twice the size of those in land-based storms.)

As snow blows and drifts, it tends to cover objects it encounters, actually holding them in place. Wind and rain in tropical systems move and lift objects and turn them into projectiles that in turn batter or penetrate what they encounter. Snow may overload a roof; tropical winds will tear it off and send it flying.

In winter, the leafless trees offer little resistance to the wind; a tree in full leaf is much more likely to come down in the wind. In the winter, the root systems are held firmly in frozen ground. Your soils are so saturated that the trees are going to go down, half of their root systems rising out of the ground, the other half actually pushing down into the saturated soils. This in turn wreaks havoc on underground utilities.

I don't know how long a nor'easter's highest winds last, but you're going to have at least tropical storm force winds for over 18 hours in your area, without letup and with higher gusts. Embedded in these winds will be tornadoes, if things weren't interesting enough.

Nor'easters don't cause refineries to shut down or cause long-lasting shortages of gasoline.

And I don't know of a nor'easter that has ever cut power to nearly 60 million people in 10 states.

In no way is a nor'easter "basically a winter hurricane". Irene is nothing you have ever experienced.

Alda Talley
Lifelong Gulf Coast and New Orleans resident, and
Survivor of Betsy, Camille, Frederick, Georges, and Katrina.

I went through Hurricane Andrew. Depending on where one is located the wind will blow unceasingly for hours and hours and sound like an animal trying to get through the window fittings. Hurricanes spawn tornadoes and there will be uprooted trees, roofs gone, and sometimes buildings flattened. When preparing for a Hurricane one should seek shelter in a place that is secure and safe obviously, but also realize that in picking same, once there you will stay there for the duration of the storm. Going outside will be very dangerous. Interiors of structures, away from windows is a must. In high-rises stairwells should be where one should go, and according to advice from New York City Website below the 10th floor.

Irene is going to hit many hard and long. Prepare now and prepare not only with supplies but where you are going to be once the hurricane hits. That is where you will be for hours. And they will be long, difficult hours.

God bless to all in weathering this storm and good luck.

We will rebuild. We will have to rebuild much.

Be prepared!

Looking over these comments I find the same blanket ignorance that many here accuse China or the Chinese people of. As an American expat (from New England) living and working in a city here larger than New York, NY, I feel that I have firsthand knowledge to provide the following commentary:

1) Please do not contrast the value systems of a developed country (USA) to that of a developing country (China) because there will always be deficiencies. It is not fair to say such things to a people who earn far far less than the average American and have to cope with stringent social mobility restraints depriving them of proper medical care and the best education (people who live in the countryside need a special permit to become a “citizen” of a major city to receive western amenities that we take for granted). China is making a concentrated effort to improve the lives of its citizens (yes, really!), and while it may not be exemplary in the eyes of the west, it is still commendable for bringing hundreds of millions of people out of poverty and supplying them with a /better/ education than generations previous...

2) People who I have talked to in my age group (20-30's) often think that Chinese traditional medicine is silly, out-dated and old-fashioned. They embrace western medicine and modern society and /are/ capable of thinking for themselves. They may not choose to do this publicly of course, but if the numerous protests and riots (mainly over corruption, migrant labor and the environment) that have happened over the past year are any indication, China is well on its way to a maturing society

3) Finally, any brutality measured against the noble animals of our planet should be met with equal condemnation but calls for an equitable response and not vitriol. You accomplish little otherwise.

Maintaining a global corporate/financial/militarist Empire (while never admitting such) is a difficult task, and yet the US nominal headquarters of that Empire is doing a fairly good job by employing cross-boarder raids with JSOCs, drones, satellite intelligence, and other stand-off violence in its territories throughout the Middle East, Africa, and now the Americas.

The effectiveness of the Empire's facade of 'standing for democracy', 'humanitarian intervention', etc. is quiet amazing in how fully this story is being believed throughout the world --- particularly be the rubes living in the country previously known as the US.

Until there is broader recognition that the world has transitioned beyond the Church-centric Empires, and Nation-state centric Empires that Paul Kennedy wrote of in his masterpiece "The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers", and understands that we are now already in a new post-nation-state era of Empire --- often pleasantly described as "Globalization", but actually Global Empire --- then such strange and deadly violence as the "Pentagon's New Map" for the Middle East and Africa, and this odd program of imperial militarism in Mexico will continue to benefit from the same level of disguise in the geopolitical body of our world that an undiagnosed cancer benefits from in a single human body.

"and so it goes" --- among the rubes in Vichy world.

Alan MacDonald
Sanford, Maine
